Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial on Seroma Management after Groin Surgery

Trial_Design.evidence: Participants were randomly assigned to either the intervention group, receiving LigaSure electrothermal bipolar sealing device, or the control group, receiving conventional techniques.

Participants.evidence: Participants were patients undergoing groin surgery, with eligibility criteria including age over 18 and no prior groin surgeries. The study was conducted in a tertiary care hospital.

Intervention.evidence: Participants were randomly assigned to either the intervention group, receiving LigaSure electrothermal bipolar sealing device, or the control group, receiving conventional techniques.

Objective.evidence: This randomised controlled trial was conducted to evaluate seroma management strategies.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the incidence of seroma formation within 30 days post-surgery.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was computer-generated, and allocation was concealed using sealed envelopes.

Blinding.evidence: Blinding was applied to outcome assessors.

Number_Randomised.evidence: A total of 200 participants were randomised, with 100 in each group, between January 2020 and June 2021.

Number_Analysed.evidence: Analysis was conducted on an intention-to-treat basis, with 98 participants in the intervention group and 97 in the control group.

Result_Outcome.evidence: In the intervention group, the seroma incidence was significantly reduced (mean difference = 12%, 95% CI 5% to 19%; p = 0.002).

Harms.evidence: Adverse events were reported in 3% of the intervention group and 1% of the control group, with mild severity.
